did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: George E. Tillitson collection on railroads,

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] George E. Tillitson collection on railroads, M0165, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection contains outlined corporate histories of railroads in the United States and Canada. The collection covers almost every railroad that ever operated in the United States and Canada and includes some records of roads that were projected though never built, and some information on street car lines and electric interurban lines. These outlines are in long hand on loose leaf 8½ × 11 inches notebook paper. They include dates of incorporation, brief sketches of the history of the line, lists of points served, lists of mileage, and occasionally time schedules, maps of lines, and lists or reports of accidents on the lines. Unfortunately, the collection is incomplete, and the information provided is much more extensive for the larger lines.
Information is arranged alphabetically by state and, within the state, alphabetically by name of company. An index of all companies listed in the files has been provided by the collector.
The Tillitson Manuscript is essentially a Railroad List which is unique in the degree of detail.

The area covered is the United States and Canada, with some material on Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, Cuba, and a little on Mexico. Whose files, together with the District of Columbia are in a separate box. The states are arranged in alphabetical order, and Canadian Provinces occupy a separate box. The material fills twenty-five file drawers.

The listings within a state are a single alphabetical listing of all Railroads (public carriers), Street Railways (of all types), Private Railroads (logging and construction RRs chiefly here) and a few others.

This includes all railroads, including the ephemeral ones conceived, yet never built, by chance that many were incorporated, but few built: Likowise, a vast number of early, independantly built short lines became absorbed into the greater large company operations; other railroads built as separate entities were actually subsidiaries or owned companies; and a vast confusion came to exist through reorganization and changes of name due to bank ruptcies and similar troubles.
These myriad changes have produced a tremendously complex structure, to which this material provides a useful and available key for students.

odd.head: Application
odd.p: Anyone wishing to become thoroughly familiar with the transportation background of an area - a state or a regional section of the United States or Canada - can do so through the medium of this manuscript.

Such a study can be concentrated on a given portion of time - early, or Railroads of Oregon in 1900, etc. - or as to type of carrier, or mode of power, steam, electric - and the companies operating, trackage involved and other pertinent data readily assembled.

Equipment - particularly motive power - is usually tabulated. Very Little operating data is given as to amount and number of trains daily; nor are there very often maps except for the lLarger company files. Timetables were not in this portion of the material.

odd.head: Special Notes
odd.p: One very useful feature of the material is further described in the two attached pages. This is the carefully annotated study of a good many of the important large railroads of the United States complete within their own files, these to be found within the official state of incorporation. Here will be included page references to the frequently huge number of small short-line roads that usually wound up by being taken in to the larger and expending Class II and I roads. Some of these files, such as the New York Central or the Pennsylvania Railroad are very big themselves.

Michigan, Wisconsin, Oregon, and Washington are large because the many lumber railroads have been extensively studied out. Within the State file for Washington, the lumber railroads make a separate alphabetical order.

dsc.head: Tabulation of distribution of Tillitson Material

did.unittitle: I. Stanford University
Hopkins Transportation Library
Individual volumes, Company Annual Reports there needed
Atlas volumes (earlier ones) Street Railway material
Set of Russell Guides : Michigan Guides (selected annually)
Rare Book Room
Complete Tillitson Railroad transcript files;

arrangement.p: arranged by states, together with indices, related material.

did.unittitle: Document Division
Required serials and many complete files from the various transportation and utility Commissioner's Reports, many states.
Law Library
All the California Law Journals; the Michigan Manuals; some of the unused balance of the serials just above.
Map Section of the Reference Room
Some Atlas volumes; all City and County maps; City Guides; regional guides; Hobbs Auto Guides and early A A A Guides.
Dudley Herbarium
Atlas volumes and early Lippincott Gaseteer.
II. Golden Gate College, San Francisco
Rand-McNally Commercial Atlas - a series.
III. Amargosa Memorial Library, San Francisco

Electric street railway material; early Soribner volumes; misc. bound volumes; many early New York state items, including canal transportation, Hudson River material. The topographic sheets also went hero.
IV. Central California Railway Club, Inc., San Jose

Yearly selection Official Guides; all remaining individual volumes; likewise, Annual Reports, and the prepaid and Mileage Lists; ICC Reports and miscellaneous items. They maintain a working library for their membership.
V. Miscellaneous
Massachusetts, Michigan, North Dakota & King County (Washington) Historical Societies were sent, on request, respective atlas volumes, other items of regional interest.

New York, New York City Omnibus Corporation (preceded by 6" of general materials, 1st of which is St. Joseph, South Bend and Southern Railroad Company)
New York, Penfield and Canal - Nevada, The Western Pacific Railroad Company
New Hampshire, Bartlett and Albany Railroad Company (initial) - Oklahoma, The Western Oklahoma Railway Company
Ohio, Addyston and Ohio River Railroad Company (this comes after general materials concerning Ohio) - Ohio, The New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad Company
Ohio (?), New York, Chicago, and St. Louis Railroad Company - Oregon, Barnes Heights and Cornell Mountain Railway Company

South Carolina, L. Anderson and Company - Pennsylvania, H.A. Bump and Company
Pennsylvania, Hagerstown and Frederick Railway Company of Pennsylvania - Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Railways Company
Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Suburban Transportation Co. - Pennsylvania, Youghiogheny Central Railway Company
Tennessee, Arkansas and Memphis Railway Bridge and Terminal Company - Texas, Gexas State Railway
